title: The Reliability Of A Dialogue Structure Coding Scheme
descriptions:
**Abstract:**

This paper evaluates the reliability of a dialogue structure coding scheme applied to a corpus of spontaneous task-oriented spoken dialogues. The coding scheme captures three levels of dialogue structure: conversational moves, games, and transactions. Moves segment the dialogue based on discourse goals and are classified into 12 categories, while games organize these moves according to shared discourse goals, including nested sub-games for clarifications. Transactions further divide the dialogue into subdialogues that correspond to major task steps.

The study demonstrates that coders can reliably reproduce key aspects of the coding, such as segmenting moves and classifying them as initiations or responses, as well as identifying subcategories within these classes. Although game coding showed somewhat lower reproducibility, individual coders were capable of developing stable internal representations of game structures. Transaction coding faced certain issues but was deemed improvable with clarification of instructions.

The coding schemes have been fully applied to the 128-dialogue Map Task Corpus and are currently employed in research on intonation, communication medium differences, aphasic dialogue, and computational dialogue systems. The study underlines the potential of the coding scheme to serve as a robust tool for investigating dialogue structure and contributes to computational applications like speech recognition and dialogue system design.

**Acknowledgments:**

This research was conducted by the Dialogue Group of the Human Communication Research Centre, funded by the Economic and Social Research Council (U.K.) and the Joint Councils Initiative. Authors JC and Al developed the transaction coding scheme and conducted reliability studies, while all authors contributed to the development of the move and game coding schemes. The paper also appreciates the input from anonymous reviewers on the manuscript draft.

**Abstract:**

This paper investigates the reliability of a dialogue structure coding scheme designed to classify segments of spoken dialogues based on utterance function, game structure, and transaction structure. The scheme was applied to a corpus of spontaneous task-oriented spoken dialogues from the Map Task Corpus. The study examines three levels of dialogue structure: conversational moves, games, and transactions. Conversational moves segment dialogues into parts with distinct discourse goals, which are then categorized into one of twelve types. Games organize moves that contribute to the same discourse goal, allowing for nested structures corresponding to embedded goals, such as clarification sub-dialogues. Transactions segment the entire dialogue into sub-dialogues relating to major task steps.

Results showed that coders could reliably reproduce key aspects of the coding, such as move segmentation and classification of moves as initiations or responses. While game coding was less reproducible, individual coders were able to reach stable internal views of game structure. Transaction coding encountered some issues but is improvable with clarifications to address common confusions. The coding schemes have been fully applied to the entire 128 dialogue Map Task Corpus and are being used to study various aspects of dialogue, such as intonation, communication modalities, and dialogue characteristics in aphasia. Additionally, the move categories have been used to train a speech recognition program and to support a computational model of move goals in a spoken dialogue system.

The work contributes to a firmer empirical basis for dialogue analysis and has potential applications in computational linguistics, speech recognition, and dialogue system design. The research was conducted by the Dialogue Group of the Human Communication Research Centre and funded by the Economic and Social Research Council (U.K.) and the Joint Councils Initiative.

Title: The Reliability Of A Dialogue Structure Coding Scheme

Abstract:

This paper presents the reliability assessment of a dialogue structure coding scheme which categorizes spontaneous task-oriented spoken dialogues based on utterance function, game structure, and higher-level transaction structure. The coding scheme, developed for the Map Task Corpus, enables the division of dialogues into moves, games, and transactions to reflect different levels of dialogue structure. Moves are individual segments that serve various discourse goals, games group together moves serving a same discourse goal and allow for embedded structures, and transactions segment the dialogue into parts that correspond to major task steps. To evaluate the coding scheme's reliability, several studies were conducted involving both in-house and external coders. The results indicated good to acceptable levels of agreement across the different levels of coding, with move segmentation and classification showing particularly high reliability. While game coding was less reproducible, individual coders developed stable views of game structure. Transaction coding faced some issues but was seen as improvable. The move and game codings have been applied to the entire 128 dialogue Map Task Corpus and are used for various linguistic studies, while transaction coding remains experimental. Overall, this coding scheme shows promise as a reliable tool for dialogue analysis across different research domains.

**Abstract**

This paper evaluates the reliability of a dialogue structure coding scheme designed for spontaneous task-oriented spoken dialogues. The coding scheme classifies dialogue into utterance functions, game structures, and higher-level transaction structures, and has been applied to the Map Task Corpus. The study investigates the reproducibility of coding across different coders and over time, assessing stability, reproducibility, and accuracy using the kappa coefficient as a measure of inter-coder agreement.

The findings reveal that coders can reliably segment dialogues into moves and classify them into initiation or response categories. They can also subclassify initiation and response types with a high level of agreement. However, the reliability of game coding is somewhat lower, although individual coders can develop consistent interpretations. Transaction coding, which segments dialogues corresponding to major task steps, presents some difficulties but can be improved by addressing common confusions.

The coding schemes have been used for the entire 128 dialogue Map Task Corpus, with game and move codings applied to research in intonation, differences in communication modes, dialogue characteristics with nonfluent aphasic participants, and as part of computational models for spoken dialogue systems. The paper concludes that the coding scheme is a robust tool for dialogue analysis, though some aspects require further refinement.

---

*Note: The abstract is a condensed version of the key points in the paper, summarizing the purpose, methodology, results, and implications of the coding scheme's reliability testing. It does not include detailed results or specific statistical figures, as these would be more appropriate for the main body of an academic paper rather than the abstract.*

    <S sid="154" ssid="1">It is important to show that subjective coding distinctions can be understood and applied by people other than the coding developers, both to make the coding credible in its own right and to establish that it is suitable for testing empirical hypotheses.</S>
    <S sid="155" ssid="2">Krippendorff (1980), working within the field of content analysis, describes a way of establishing reliability, which applies here.</S>

    <S sid="158" ssid="5">The second is reproducibility, or intercoder variance, which requires different coders to code in the same way.</S>
    <S sid="159" ssid="6">The third is accuracy, which requires coders to code in the same way as some known standard.</S>

  <SECTION title="5." number="8">
    <S sid="291" ssid="1">Subjective coding has been described for three different levels of task-oriented dialogue structure, called conversational moves, games, and transactions, and the reliability of all three kinds of coding discussed.</S>
    <S sid="292" ssid="2">The codings were devised for use with the HCRC Map Task Corpus.</S>
    <S sid="293" ssid="3">The move coding divides the dialogue up into segments corresponding to the different discourse goals of the participants and classifies the segments into 1 of 12 different categories, some of which initiate a discourse expectation and some of which respond to an existing expectation.</S>
    <S sid="294" ssid="4">The coders were able to reproduce the most important aspects of the coding reliably, such as move segmentation, classifying moves as initiations or responses, and subclassifying initiation and response types.</S>
    <S sid="295" ssid="5">The game coding shows how moves are related to each other by placing into one game all moves that contribute to the same discourse goal, including the possibility of embedded games, such as those corresponding to clarification questions.</S>
    <S sid="296" ssid="6">The game coding was somewhat less reproducible but still reasonable.</S>
    <S sid="297" ssid="7">Individual coders can come to internally stable views of game structure.</S>
    <S sid="298" ssid="8">Finally, the transaction coding divides the entire dialogue into subdialogues corresponding to major steps in the participants' plan for completing the task.</S>
    <S sid="299" ssid="9">Although transaction coding has some problems, the coding can be improved by correcting a few common confusions.</S>
    <S sid="300" ssid="10">Game and move coding have been completed on the entire 128 dialogue Map Task Corpus; transaction coding is still experimental.</S>
    <S sid="301" ssid="11">Game and move coding are currently being used to study intonation both in oneword English utterances (Kowtko 1995) and in longer utterances across languages (Grice et al. 1995), the differences between audio-only, face-to-face, text-based, and video-mediated communication (Doherty-Sneddon et al., forthcoming; Newlands, Anderson, and Mullin 1996), and the characteristics of dialogue where one of the participants is a nonfluent Broca-type aphasic (Merrison, Anderson, and Doherty-Sneddon 1994).</S>
    <S sid="302" ssid="12">In addition, the move coded corpus has been used to train a program to spot the dialogue move category based on typical word patterns, in aid of speech recognition (Bird et al. 1995).</S>
    <S sid="303" ssid="13">The move categories themselves have been incorporated into a computational model of move goals within a spoken dialogue system in order to help the system predict what move the user is making (Lewin et al. 1993).</S>
